name: Particle Fleet: Emergence
description: Build and design your own fleets and stand opposed to the Particulate in this physics/strategy/RTS/fleet hybrid. Build partially destructible and self repairing ships that interact with enemies less controlled by some scripted logic and more driven by a real time massive physics particle simulation.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or later Processor: Dual Core 2Ghz Memory: 3 GB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 2 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or later Processor: Quad Core 2Ghz Memory: 4 GB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0c Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 4 GB available space

reviews.review_text: While I enjoyed and am recommending Particle Fleet, I consider Creeper World 3 to be a deeper, richer and more rewarding game. Both games will reward players who like to find efficient solutions to tactical problems/puzzles. If you are a casual player, maybe you will enjoy Particle Fleet more. But if you really like to sink your teeth (and your brain) into a game, I think Creeper World 3 offers significantly more value per dollar and per hour of gameplay.

Good stuff. Haven't gotten into it quite as much as the other Creeper World games but it's a solid evolution of them--definitely feels very different. If you like tower defense/RTS/other Creeper World games you'll enjoy this for sure.

If you enjoyed the Creeper World games, stop reading now and just buy this. The core gameplay is familiar and improved upon in several ways.  This is one of those strategy games where you can sink your teeth into every mission and take things at your own pace (for the most part). I pause frequently during the gameplay to re-assess the situation and consider my next moves.  I love that the map has so much going on, with all the particles floating about, but you don't really need to be aware of it all at once. You can take over the map one area at a time (depending on the size of your fleet and your tactical prowess).  The game does have a slightly steeper learning curve than CW. You are given ships that contain modules that aren't fully explained in the tutorials. I recommend reading the Help in the main menu after playing a couple missions so you can digest everything that has been thrown at you.

Having spend more than 40 hours during 2 weeks pre release there is no way this is not going to be a highly recommended game from me.  Not going into details on what the game is about here, just watch some videos or better yet grab the demo from the developers website and see for yourself, but I will say what to expect. A campaign which will introduce you to all the game concepts with a great difficulty curve and storyline which will take you 10-15 hours to complete. Some maps from alpha stages of the game, many featured on the regular videos posted during development, ranging from easy to hard which will give you another 10 hours of gameplay. Mission and ship editors for those who want to get into this and access to maps uploaded by other players, giving infinite possibilities to what you may find. The last game from Knuckle Cracker, Creeper World 3, currently features more than 30000 maps created by users which can be easily sorted using a variety of filters, including some which introduced completely new game modes and where I have spend more than 200 hours, at least half of these playing modes initially never intended by the developer! So far even pre release there are already over 50 user created maps available, and having played a couple of dozen I can say there are already at least a couple of gems in there. And if that is not enough a random mission generator, where you can tweak dozens of different variables to get a customized experience, or just hit 'random everything' and go with a completely random map, which can be anything from a walk in the park to almost impossible to beat.  Disclaimer: Since I´m a big fan of the other Knuckle Cracker games I have been eagerly anticipating the release of this game and following its development through the regularly posted videos and posts on their website. I got a free key on a giveaway from the developer giving access to some people from the community to the later stages of beta to help ensure a smooth launch. That said I haven´t encountered any major issues and the few bugs were being regularly patched as soon as being reported.

I have never played any Creeper World games so my impression is that this is a 'tower-defense style RTS where you have to advance into the spawn points'. It is difficult to actually lose any map included with the game, but many of the maps available from the public exchange are very difficult. The long term playability comes from making your own ships in the editor and replaying maps to test your ship theory. The fun comes from finding a way out of a stale-mate with the particles.

Awesome game, well recommended. If you liked the creeper world series, this similarly fun to play. Great replay value and the graphics are definitely a whole lot improved since creeper world 3.   For those new to it, the levels in the campaign are usually easy to figure out but the real challenge is in beating the level quickly. So, you can grind it out for an hour or figure out how to do it in a few minutes. This makes the game attractive for casual playing as well as for hard core strategists. To win, you need to optimize strategy and resource usage and make use of all the various strengths and weaknesses of your own and enemy units. What adds fun is that the enemy is beautifully rendered particles that move and cluster in all sorts of complex patterns. It can crowd you and and you counter with guns and armor to overcome it. You beat the game by by taking out particle emitters and gaining control of the energy resources on the map.  With creeper world 3 there have been lots of users that ended up writing new levels and using the built in scripting language to tweak the game dynamics or even introduce new game modes. This game has similar potentia and comes with all the tools to do thisl and there already loads of community maps. You'll do the campaign in about 10-15 hours and then move on to the user provided maps, This is where the real fun starts. These unlock after you complete the first ten levels, which sort of function as a tutorial as well.
Creeper World 3 was awesome, they managed to make a new game at least this good if not better. Knukle Cracker, i love you.

This is kind of like a tower defense game, only you do not have a line of creeps trying to make it across the map to some spot. Instead you have a fluid enemy in which you must destroy several spawners. If you have played Creeper world and liked it, then you will enjoy this game. It is a good game, but not a great game, however it is quite cheap, so there is that.  My only complaint is after finishing the story missions, there are some extra scenerio missions. I found them frustrating, especially because the game 'cheats'. For example there is some problematic emitter. You get your fleet near it and you have it locked down. You kill all the partilces it makes as fast as you make them. Then you move in for the kill shot, and then suddenly the emitter cranks out 20x as much as it did before and blows away your entire fleet. Its just stupid and I didn't find those very fun.

As a fan of the Creeper World series, and someone who followed the dev blog for this game, I'm not ashamed to say this game has been a very rare day one buy for me. It's got a lot of the same sensitiblities present in the Creeper World games, but it brings enough new ideas and mechanics to be different, resulting in something recognizeable, but fresh.  The story mode seemed relatively short to me, but like previous Knuckle Cracker games, a big draw is the ability to have endless randomized maps and easily accessible community maps. Each map can also use custom ships which can lead to some very nice surprises sometimes.  If you like Creeper World 3, you'll probably enjoy Particle Fleet. If you don't, probably not. Personally I'm sure I'll sink a lot of hours into this.

If you've played the Creeper World games, this is similar. The big difference is the de-emphasis on resource gathering and base-building, and a bigger emphasis on battle control. There is a unit limit. You can't win purely off of turtling into a strong economy, you have to turtle into taking objectives here and there.   There is much more emphasis on movement and putting your ships in the right position. The 'creep' can now react to your presence, so you have to pick your battles carefully. Sometimes your full army can only take one objective at a time; sometimes it can take multiple objectives at once.  For those who haven't played creeper world, try the free demo on Kongregate / the interwebs. If you like that kind of slow RTS where you have perfect information and the enemy AI is predictable, you'll probably like this game.

As someone who has been following the development of this game since the very first preview video, the game certainly meets expectations. I've played every single creeper world game and can say without a doubt that the gameplay in Particle Fleet is every bit what I expected it to be.   It is very hard to compare it to a game like creeper world 3, which had layers and layers of content, while on release Particle Fleet seems slightly lacking in that department. Particle fleet does have extra missions outside of the main story the same as creeper world 3, but creeper world's bonus content was massive, for better or worse. Not to say this is a bad thing, but it touches on another point about the game I'd like to touch on.  The story in Particle fleet is, without spoiling the epxerience, pleasing to anyone who has played the previous creeper world games, but ultimately left me wanting more, and hoping for the possibility of additional content to answer the many questions the game raises but leaves open.  The gameplay is really where the game shines, even if a lot of other features add to it (like the ship builder or mission editor). Quite a departure from the play style of creeper world, the game is less about ground control and maintaining an all around front line, and more about directed front line pushes. The enemy is no longer fluid in nature, and is more actively aggressive. The creep would roll over you if allowed, and demanded an all around defense of your controled area while being offensive. Particle Fleet plays similarly in some ways, but the particulate are harder to predict and wont hesitate to rush a weakness if they come across it, and unlike creeper world, where you would just push your front line close enough to an emitter to take it out, the particulate are not fond of the player getting in range of the emiter and often demands a large ammount of available firepower be dedicated to defending the laithe ships.  Over all I would say creeper world 3 had the potential to be much more punishingly dificult at times in the story (specifically farbor), but Particle fleet still manages to present a satisfying challenge.  4.5/5, story feels incomplete in the end, gameplay is a fantastic change of pace from creeper world, and while the extra content is lacking compared the the last game by knucklecracker, it is more than enough to be satisfactory and give hours upon hours of entertainment.
